data.title: The High Cost of Loving (1958)
data.meta_description: Middle-aged middle-manager Jim Fry, with the same company for fifteen years, is in a comfortable rut. But life becomes less predictable when he doesn't receive an invitation to an important luncheon being held by the new company president. Convinced that he's about to lose his job, Jim begins to mull over his limited prospects when his wife confirms that she's pregnant.
data.text:
Half watched this but I managed to see it from start to finish so it gets logged even if it seemed like the movie was nothing more than Jose Ferrer worrying, agonizing, and then raging about working for his company for 15 years and never getting a promotion or anything. (So it's like the mildest button down version of "Falling Down" imaginable)

There's a big important lunch that the higher ups in his company have where they kinda groom a bunch of junior employees for managerial positions and when he finds out that he wasn't included on the guest list he starts to freak out about his future with the company. Meanwhile his wife played by Gena Rowlands finds out…

In the post-Mad Men era, films about corporate America made during the 1950s and 60s have taken on additional interest. I’m not sure if Matthew Weiner specifically named this as one of his inspirations, but it easily could have been. José Ferrer’s fifth film as director taps into the anxieties of many “loyal” employees who were, in fact, employed entirely “at will” during the post-WWII boom years. It revolves around a misunderstanding that, absent any other information, gnaws away at Ferrer’s sense of security: his company has recently merged with another, and amid water-cooler hypothesizing about who will stay and be promoted and who will go, an oversight that leaves his name off of an important luncheon invitation list seems…
